div.head:
Embleme 7. Of the Secrets of Nature.
A chicken is flying out of the nest, which falls againe into the nest.

lg.l: The bird of Jove had nested on a rockerock,
Where Shee brought forth, and fed her tender flocke:
Out flyes the eldest having wings and traynetrain,
PulldPulled by the naked nestling backe againe
To the deserted nest: you hitt the nayle,
If you know how to joyne them head and tayle.

div.head: Discourse 7.
div.ab:
What Hippocrates, the defender and propugnator of Physicians, affirms of hu
mors, that they are different and many in man, and not one onely, otherwise
various diseases, could not arise, that wee perceive to be true of the elements
of the world: for if there was but one onely element, there could be noe-
mutation of it into another, noe generation nor corruption, yea all things
would be one immutable thing, and noe meteors, mineralls, plants, and
animalls could be naturally from theme produced. For this reason the su
preme Creator composed the whole systeme of this world of divers and-
contrary natures, namely of light and heavy, hott and cold, moist and dry-
that one might be affinity passe into the other, and soe a composition be
made of bodyes, which might be very different one from another in essence,
qualityes, virtues, and effects: for in things perfectly mixed are the light Ele
ments, as fire and aire, and allso the heavy, as earth and water, which are soe
æqually tempered together, that one recedes not from the other, but suffers itselfe
to be easily taken and held by the other as neighbour by neighbour: Earth and aire
are contrary one to the other, soe fire and water, yea notwithstanding fire main
tainesmaintains freindship with aire by heat comon to both, with earth by siccity: soe
aire with water, and water with earth: by which means they are all joyned
by bonds of affinity or rather consanguinity, and doe remayne together in
one composition, which, if it abound with the light Elements, elevates the-
heavy with it, if with the heavy, weighs downe the light with it: This is decla
red by the two Eagles, one with wings, the other without, of which that-
which endeavoured to fly is restrained by the other an example hereof is evident
in the fight of the Falcon and Heron, for the Falcon soaring higher in-
the aire by his Speedy flying, takes and tears the Heron with his Talons, by
whose weight both fall to the ground: The contrary appeared in the-
artificiall dove or Automa of Archytas, where heavy things were lifted up
by light, that is, the wooden body of it caryedcarried into the aire by the-
Spirit includes within: In the Philosophicall subject the light things doe
first prædominatepredominate the heavy, as to plenty, but they are overcome by vir
tue of the heavy things, and in processe of time the Eagles wings are cut-
of, and one very great bird (namely an Ostrich) is made of two, which
can consume iron, and which being impeded by weight runnsruns more upon
the earth, than flyes in the aire, though it hath goodly wings: Concerning
this or the like Hermes (as the Author of Aurora chapt. 5. affirms) writes thus:
I have considered a bird worthy to be had in estimation by the wise, which
flyes when it is in Aries, Cancer, Libra, or Capricorne, and you will never
faylefail of it in pure mynesmines, and rocky mountains: Concerning the same Se
nior in Tabula, where two are soon, one volatile the other without wings,
whereof one holds the others tayle by its beakebeak, that they cannot easily be
seperated: For this is the device and machination of universall nature,
allwayes to rayseraise heavy things by light, and likewise to depressedepress light
things by heavy, as the Author of the perfect Magistery declarethdeclares, who
constitutes seven minerall spirits, as it were erratickeerratic Starrs, and-
Discourse 7.
soe many metallicke bodyes, as fixed Starrs, and enjoynsenjoins these to be
wedded to those: from theme allso Aristotle the Chymist, the Spirit, sayth hee,
having dissolved the body and Soule, soe as to exist in their forme, doth not
remaine a fixed thing, unlesse you operate upon it: now operation is to joyne-
it with the body, from which you præpared it at first: because the Spirit is-
thereby prevented from flight being mixed with the supersistences of the-
body: the light Elements, namely aire and fire, as a learned man declares,
doe in Camphore oversway the heavy; and therefore it is sayd wholywholly to ex
hale and evaporate into aire. In Argent vive, the flowers of Sulphur, Anti
mony, the Salt of Harts blood, Sal Armoniacke, and such others, the earth-
flyes with the aire into the AlembickeAlembic, and is not seperated from it. In Gold,
glasse, Diamond, the Stone Smyris, Granats, and the like, the Elements-
doe notwithstanding fire remayne along time joyned without detriment,-
and the earth retainesretains those things which are left in itselfe. In other com
bustibles division and separation of one thing from another is effected, soe
that the ashes are left in the bottomebottom, the water, aire, and fire fly up
wards: wee must not therefore have respect to the unæquallunequal composition of
these last, being not soe strongly mixd, nor to the comixtioncommixtion of the first,
though more durable, yet volatile, but to the solidity, constancy, and fixity
of the midle: for soe the bird without wings will detainedetain that which hath,-
and the fixed substance will fix the volatile, which must necessarily be
done. . . . . . . . . .
